docs.lead_paragraph: IN January 2004, Jennie Somogyi, one of New York City Ballet's strongest principal dancers, suffered an injury so severe and unlikely that the company's doctors initially could not diagnose it. While performing the rigorous lead in ''Tchaikovsky Piano Concerto No. 2,'' she tore a tendon in her left foot. The process of getting back into shape has been painfully slow. Ms. Somogyi had reconstructive surgery more than a year ago, but the most basic physical therapy, which she attends twice a week, didn't begin until three months later. She first had to relearn how to walk.
docs.abstract: Gia Kourlas interviews New York City Ballet dancer Jennie Somogyi about her difficult recovery from a torn tendon in her foot; she had surgery and continues with physical therapy, hoping to be able to return to dancing soon; photo (M)
docs.snippet: A year after a serious foot injury, a ballerina gazes on atrophied legs and asks, "Whose body is this?"...

headline.main: Learning to Walk, Hoping for Calluses

docs.lead_paragraph: Interspecies interactions are all over YouTube. Yes, they’re cute, but are they useful to scientists?
docs.abstract: Popularity of online videos depicting different species of animals playing and showing affection to one another has prompted some researchers to look deeper into science of cross-species interactions; scientists are studying what causes some animals to reach across species lines and extent to which one type of animal can learn behavior of another, as well as effect of captivity on interactions.
docs.snippet: Interspecies interactions are all over YouTube. Yes, they’re cute, but are they useful to scientists?...

docs.lead_paragraph: In a cafeteria recently converted to offer quick training in place of quick meals, Laura Tyler of Tulsa, Okla., waited patiently next to a metal detector, cuddling a plastic baby doll a bit smaller than her own youngest child. John Stewart, until recently a construction worker from Claremore, Okla., asked the standard questions: ''Any metal? Keys? Cell phone, beeper?'' They are both learning to be airport security screeners, members of a class of about 6,000 who started training in more than 100 sites this week, practicing on one another and on sample suitcases in an urgent push to replace all contract screeners around the country with federal employees by Nov. 19.

headline.main: Learning the Etiquette of Patting Down Passengers

docs.lead_paragraph: THE light-brown complexion of Vilda Vera Mayuga glows in a way that suggests she devotedly visits a dermatologist, sits for facials or drowns her skin in expensive creams and serums. But Ms. Mayuga, 30, a lawyer and native Puerto Rican who lives in Manhattan, hasn't been to the dermatologist in more than five years. Instead, she relies on remedios caseros -- home remedies that the women in her family have used for generations -- as the cornerstone of her otherwise spare skin-care regimen. ''I like to use the cream that comes out of the cactus,'' she said, referring to sabila, or aloe vera, which she uses for dry skin, dark spots and scars, her most common problems. ''You cut it and you squeeze it out and you boil it, and then you put it against your skin.''
docs.abstract: Skin care companies are introducing lines of products geared for Latinos--nation's fastest-growing ethnic group; scientists and dermatologists are just beginning to study whether Hispanic skin differs among its subgroups and from other ethnicities; photos (M)

headline.main: Learning To Speak To Latino Complexions

docs.lead_paragraph: AT Coca-Cola, Roberto C. Goizueta remains a legend, the chief executive whose vision and drive transformed the giant company into a global power. For his successor, M. Douglas Ivester, mastery of the inner workings of the Coke system could not make up for an uninterrupted streak of falling profits and personal faux pas. Now the corner office at Coke is to be occupied by Douglas N. Daft, a cheerful, unassuming Australian who spent 30 years rising through the ranks. Practically a stranger in Atlanta, because of his overseas postings and constant travel, in just a few weeks he has turned the world of Coca-Cola upside down.
docs.abstract: Interview with new Coca-Cola Co head Douglas N Daft on his plan to restructure company, pushing worldwide decision-making down to local level; company's recent woes discussed; graphs of slowing sales growth and of stock price; drawing; photos (M)

headline.main: Learning to Think Smaller at Coke

docs.lead_paragraph: No longer seen as domestic drudgery, sewing is embraced by the do-it-yourself crowd — both female and male.
docs.abstract: New generation of young men and women are embracing sewing as a form of self-expression and a way to assert their independence; numbers of members at craft education centers have increased over the past year, and sewing-machine sales in the United States are booming.

docs.lead_paragraph: ''The Body Clock Guide to Better Health,'' by Dr. Michael Smolensky and Lynne Lamberg. Owl Books/Henry Holt & Company, $16. Most of us can tell time, but few of us know how to tell body time, according to the authors of this book on (take your pick) chronobiology, chronomedicine, chronotherapy and chronorecord-keeping.
